conversation.message: Hello School_D admissions team—I'm Student_C. School_D is my first-choice school, and I’m very excited about the possibility of joining your community. I’m applying because I strongly prefer School_D over all other options and would gladly accept a place if offered. Thank you for considering my application.
conversation.thought: My top choice is School_D, but School_D ranks me 3rd (behind Student_D and Student_E). Student_D also ranks School_D last, so they likely won’t apply there; however Student_E ranks School_D 4th and could apply later. To maximize my chance at my true #1, I should apply to School_D immediately before it potentially fills, since there’s no benefit to waiting in this one-seat market.

conversation.message:
Dear Student_C,

Thank you for your application and for sharing that School_D is your first choice. We’re pleased to offer you admission to School_D.

[ACTION: Please confirm your acceptance on your side as required by the process.]

[ACCEPT]
conversation.thought: School_D has quota 1 and priority order: D > E > C > B > A. Student_C is 3rd on our list and has applied in round 1, stating School_D is first choice, so acceptance would likely lock a stable match. However, Student_D (our top choice) prefers School_C first and School_D last, so is unlikely to apply here unless rejected elsewhere; Student_E ranks School_D 4th; Student_B ranks School_D 2nd; Student_A ranks School_D 3rd. Given the uncertainty of receiving Student_D and the risk of losing Student_C if we delay, accepting Student_C now secures a high-priority match (top-3) within quota.

conversation.message: Dear School_C Admissions, I’m Student_E and I’m formally applying because School_C is my first choice. I’m highly motivated to join your community and would enthusiastically accept an offer if selected. Thank you for considering my application.
conversation.thought: My top choice is School_C, so I should apply immediately. Although School_C’s priority list ranks me 4th, applying now is still best because waiting only increases the chance higher-priority students (especially Student_C and Student_B) take the single seat. I will send a clear, committed application emphasizing fit and strong interest.

conversation.message:
Dear Student_E,

Thank you for your application and for sharing your strong interest in School_C. After reviewing applications received this round and considering our limited capacity, we’re not able to offer you admission at this time.

We appreciate your effort and wish you the very best in the rest of the process.

Sincerely,
School_C Admissions
conversation.thought: As School_C, my true priority is C > B > D > E > A. In this round I received [APPLY] from Student_D and Student_E. Student_D is ranked higher than Student_E on my list, and both indicate School_C is their first choice, so accepting Student_E now would likely block a better (higher-priority) match with Student_D given my quota is 1. Therefore I should reject Student_E to preserve the seat for Student_D.

conversation.message: Hello School_C admissions team. I’m Student_D and School_C is my first-choice school. I’m excited about the academic environment and would be honored to join if admitted. I’m ready to commit and accept promptly if offered a place. Thank you for considering my application.
conversation.thought: My top choice is School_C. I have relatively strong priority there (3rd after Student_C and Student_B), so applying immediately gives me a real chance to secure my first choice before other high-priority applicants fill the single seat.

While it’s possible higher-priority students (Student_C or Student_B) could apply later, I cannot hold a seat without accepting someone now, and Student_D is a strong, acceptable match within my list. Given quota 1 and the current applicants, I should accept Student_D.

conversation.message: Dear School_A Admissions, I’m Student_A and I’m applying because School_A is my first-choice school. Your academic environment and expectations are exactly what I’m looking for, and if admitted I will accept and enroll. Thank you for considering my application.
conversation.thought: My top choice is School_A, so I should apply immediately. Although School_A ranks me 3rd (behind Student_B and Student_D), an early application gives me the best chance if higher-priority students go elsewhere (Student_B prefers School_B first; Student_D prefers School_C first). conversation.message: Dear Student_A, thank you for your thoughtful application and for naming School_A as your first choice. At this time, we’re unable to offer you admission in this round. We appreciate your interest in School_A and wish you the very best in the process.
conversation.thought: Student_A is applying now and ranks 3rd on School_A’s true priority list (behind Student_B and Student_D). With quota 1, accepting now would lock in Student_A and prevent matching with higher-priority Student_B or Student_D if they later apply. Given full information: Student_B’s top choice is School_B (School_B ranks Student_B 3rd), so Student_B may not come to School_A unless rejected by School_B and School_D. Student_D’s top choice is School_C (School_C ranks Student_D 3rd) and Student_D is top priority at School_B and School_D, so Student_D is likely to be taken elsewhere and may never apply to School_A. Still, to maximize chance of matching with a higher-priority student, the best move is to reject Student_A now and keep the seat open for Student_B (our top priority) should they become available; Student_A has strong outside options but may also be accepted by School_A if still available later. Immediate accept is safe but not optimal for priority maximization.

conversation.message: Hello School_B Admissions Committee—I'm Student_B. School_B is my first-choice school, and I’m formally applying. I’m highly motivated to join your community and would accept an offer immediately if admitted. Thank you for considering my application.

Given the one-shot accept/reject rule on an [APPLY], it is better to reject now and keep the seat open to pursue higher-priority candidates in subsequent rounds.

conversation.message:
Dear School_E Admissions,

I’m Student_E, and I’m writing to formally apply again for the remaining open seat. I understand I was not selected in prior rounds, but since School_E is still available, I want to be completely clear: if offered admission now, I will accept immediately and withdraw from any other options.

I’m ready to contribute as a focused, reliable student and be an active, positive member of the School_E community. Thank you for reconsidering my application in this final stage.

Sincerely,
Student_E
conversation.thought: Only School_E remains unmatched, and it is on my true preference list (though last). To avoid ending unmatched, I should apply again but with a clearer commitment and a concise rationale for fit, while acknowledging prior rejections and emphasizing immediate acceptance if offered.

conversation.message:

Please confirm your acceptance, and we will proceed with the final enrollment steps.

Sincerely,

conversation.thought: Student_E is 4th on School_E’s true priority list (A, C, B, E, D). We have rejected Student_E in prior rounds to preserve the seat for higher-priority students (A/C/B). However, in round 5 our inbox contains only Student_E, and we still have 1 open seat. There is no direct evidence that Student_A/Student_C/Student_B will apply to School_E soon (School_E is last choice for all students except Student_B where it is 4th; for Student_A/C it is 5th). Waiting longer risks ending unmatched, which is worse than accepting a listed student. Since Student_E is on our acceptable list and is explicitly committing to accept immediately, accepting now secures a match and avoids vacancy risk.
